thread.title: Al Jean talks what’s ahead for The Simpsons
thread.title_full: Al Jean talks what’s ahead for The Simpsons | DailyTelegraph

author: Andrew Fenton
title: Al Jean talks what’s ahead for The Simpsons
text:
THE Simpsons’ showrunner Al Jean says that not only would the long running series have survived the loss of voice actor Harry Shearer — they actually made more than a third of the current season without him.
Shearer, the voice behind Mr Burns, Ned Flanders, Principal Skinner and Kent Brockman, walked earlier this year in a standoff over contract negotiations. Jean isn’t entirely sure why: there was never any question of offering him more money than the other five main cast, and the voice actor’s concern about “the freedom to do other work” didn’t square with the fact he can record his dialogue over the internet.
It was a high stakes game of chicken, but Jean says the show was contractually bound to go on.
“We would have had to replace him if he didn’t sign.
“There was never even a time where there was a choice whether or not to do the show.”
In the end eight episodes were recorded without Shearer. After he relented, they were able to go back and add his characters and voices to the finished programs.
Other Stories The horror of MH17’s final 90 seconds News 0 comments Who were Playboy’s Aussie stars? Sydney Confidential 0 comments Terror threats: ‘Thousands will die’ National Chloe: I’m not used to the fame Sydney Confidential 0 comments Knights sign half, Raiders re-sign centre Nrl 0 comments Esquire names the sexiest woman alive Books 0 comments “It’s funny because I don’t think if you watch the shows you’ll even notice any absence,” he says, adding they always wanted Shearer back. “It was always our preference to sign him and we never read anybody (else for the role).”
Show must go on ... The Simpsons executive producer Al Jean. SMITHERS IS FINALLY COMING OUT AS GAY
IS THIS THE MAN TO SAVE THE SIMPSONS
THINK YOU’RE A SIMPSONS’ EXPERT?
When Jean joined the show as a writer in 1989 the internet didn’t exist, and word processors were a fancy new technology. He’s been showrunner since 2001. Despite lasting for 27 seasons so far (and another season is already underway) the passion of the fans hasn’t diminished, as evidenced by the backlash to reports Marge and Homer were getting a divorce (in part due to a love interest played by Lena Dunham) in the first of the new episodes. “We never said that!” Jean says. “It was misQuote: d by CNN and the backlash was astounding. It was kind of touching that it meant so much to so many people.”
Historic ... The Simpsons predates the internet. Other episodes feature Sideshow Bob finally killing Bart — it’s a Halloween episode so it doesn’t count — a homage to the film Boyhood called Barthood and Sofia Vergara shows up as Bart’s new teacher.
“He has a crush on her and so does Skinner so they have a rivalry going,” he says. She may return. “She works about a block away so it’s easy to bring her back and she was really pleasant to work with.”
Bart hasn’t had a regular teacher since Marcia Wallace, who voiced Edna Krabappel passed away in 2013. “We were never going to have anyone else do that character,” Jean says. “It’s a sad sort of function of the show being on the air 26 years.”
A more recent loss in March was Sam Simon, who developed the show with Matt Groening and James L. Brooks. “He was to me the person most instrumental in transforming Matt’s characters from the (original Tracey Ullman Show shorts) into a fully-fledged half-hour show. He taught me how to run The Simpsons and was a real mentor to me.” And like Shearer he was famous for being as difficult as he was creative. “He described himself as difficult and who am I to argue?” Jean says wryly. “But he’s also a guy who was very talented and wanted things to be as good as they could be.” Jean predicts The Simpsons will be renewed for another two seasons, bringing it to 30 seasons and 669 episodes. “And it’s just my opinion (probably) 50/50 (chance of continuing) after that. I don’t think it will (end) because of ratings or expense, it will just be because there’d be a feeling that we have done enough. I don’t feel that now.”
Home wrecker? Lena Dunham guest stars in the season 27 premiere of The Simpsons. THE SIMPSONS, WEDNESDAY, ELEVEN, 8.30PM

The attractive couple have three children together, daugher India-Rose and twin boys Tristan and Sasha. Picture: AAP 2 of 14 Kris Jenner, 59, and Corey Gamble, 34, are rumoured to have met in August last year at designer Riccardo Tisci’s birthday party in Ibiza. The Kardashian matriarch’s new beau works for Justin Bieber’s manager Scooter Braun. Picture: Getty 3 of 14 Deborra Lee Furness, 59, and Hugh Jackman, 46, met in 1995 while working together on television show Correlli and then wed the following year in Victoria. They have two children together, son Oscar and daughter Ava. Picture: Getty 4 of 14 Eva Mendes, 41, and Ryan Gosling, 34, got together after filming The Place Beyond The Pines in 2011. The genetically blessed coupled welcomed their first child in September, baby girl Esmeralda Amada Gosling. Picture: Snapper 5 of 14 Cameron Diaz, 43, and Benji Madden, 36, tied the knot in an intimate ceremony at the actress’s Beverly Hills mansion in January. Although the couple have known each other for years, the big day came after less than a year of dating. Picture: Getty 6 of 14 Elle Macpherson, 51, and billionaire beau Jeffrey Soffer, 45, originally dated for two years before breaking up in 2012. Upon reconciling the following year, the duo married in Fiji. Picture: Snapper 7 of 14 Janet Jackson, 49, and Wissam Al Mana, 39, met in 2009 after the singer gave a special performance in the Middle East. After two years of dating the singer tied the knot with the Qatar billionare in a private ceremony in 2012. Picture: Getty 8 of 14 Julianne Moore, 54, and Bart Freundlich, 45, first met in 1996 when they worked on the film The Myth of Fingerprints. The couple had two children together, daughter Liv and son Caleb, before tying the knot in 2003. Picture: Getty 9 of 14 Susan Sarandon, 69, and Jonathon Bricklin, 31, met on a roadtrip to Chile in early 2010. The actress reportedly got together with her toyboy several months after splitting from partner of 23 years Tim Robbins, who was also 12 years her junior. Picture: Getty 10 of 14 X Want to see more?
